statement:
We start with a definition.

Let $G$ be a group. An equivalence relation $\sim$ on $G$ is called a
*group congruence* if it is compatible with the group structure, ie.
when the following holds

-   $\forall a,b,a',b'\in G,\quad (a\sim a'\,\,\, \text{and}
        \,\,\, b\sim b')  \Rightarrow ab \sim a'b'$

-   $\forall a,b\in G,\quad a\sim b \Rightarrow a^{-1}\sim b^{-1}\,. $

So a group congruence is a that additionally preserves the unary
operation of taking inverse.

It turns out that group congruences correspond to normal subgroups:

An equivalence relation $\sim$ is a group congruence if and only if
there is a normal subgroup such that
$$\forall a,b \in G, \quad a\sim b \Longleftrightarrow ab^{-1}\in H\,.$$

Let $H$ be a *normal* subgroup of $G$ and let $\sim_H$ be the
equivalence relation $H$ defines in $G$. To see that this equivalence
relation is compatible with the group operation note that if
$a'\sim_H a$ and $b'\sim_H b$ then there are elements $h_1$ and $h_2$ of
$H$ such that $a' = ah_1$ and $b' = b
  h_2$. Furthermore since $H$ is normal in $G$ there is an element
$h_3\in H$ such that $h_1b = bh_3$. Then we have $$\begin{aligned}
  a'b'&=ah_1bh_2 \\
      &=abh_3h_2 \end{aligned}$$ which gives that $a'b'\sim ab$.

To prove the converse, assume that $\sim$ is an equivalence relation
compatible with the group operation and let $H$ be the equivalence class
of the identity $e$. We will prove that $\sim \,= \,\sim_H$. We first
prove that $H$ is a normal subgroup of $G$. Indeed if $a\sim e$ and $b
  \sim e$ then by the compatibility we have that $ab^{1} \sim ee^{-1}$,
that is $ab^{-1}\sim e$; so that $H$ is a subgroup of $G$. Now if
$g\in G$ and $h\in H$ we have $$\begin{aligned}
    h\sim e &\Rightarrow ghg^{-1} \sim geg^{-1}\\
            &\Rightarrow ghg^{-1} \sim e\\            
            &\Rightarrow ghg^{-1} \in H\,.
  \end{aligned}$$ Therefore $H$ is a normal subgroup of $G$. Now
consider two elements $a$ and $b$ of $G$. To finish the proof observe
that for $a,b\in G$ we have $$\begin{aligned}
   a\sim_H b   &\Rightarrow ab^{-1}\in H\\ 
               &\Rightarrow ab^{-1} \sim e\\
               &\Rightarrow (ab^{-1})b \sim eb\\ 
               &\Rightarrow a \sim b 
 \end{aligned}$$ and $$\begin{aligned}
   a\sim b &\Rightarrow ab^{-1} \sim bb^{-1}\\
               &\Rightarrow ab^{-1} \sim e\\
               &\Rightarrow a\sim_H b\,.
 \end{aligned}$$
names: correspondence of normal subgroups and group congruences
